channel.title: Mustafa Dane's Personal Website
channel.description: Recent content on Mustafa Dane's Personal Website

item.title: SPL/IT
item.description:
$PL/IT is a mobile tab splitting app for friends who go out to eat but have different spending habits. iOS and Android users can upload photos of their receipts and claim ownership of each item in that receipt. Once the event is closed, each user is shown how much they should pay or charge other users in the event.

Development

This was built using Google’s Cloud Vision API with a front end in React Native and a back-end in Firebase.

We wrote a custom algorithm to parse the results from Cloud Vision’s API into line items which we store in Firebase’s real-time database. Firebase supports not only our app’s database and authentication, but also user interaction. In addition, this non-relational database allows us to set up subscriptions to an SDK to handle queries almost instantly.

Contributors
  • Brittany Hill
  • Julianne Crawford
  • Lotus Tan
  • Mustafa Dane

item.title: Adaptify
item.description:
Adaptive Playlist Experience

Have you ever had a song in your playlist that you keep skipping? Then, use Adaptify to have an adaptive playlist. Any song that are skipped 3 times will be deleted from your playlist!

  • Utilized: Spotify Android SDK and API, React Native, Heroku deployed server with Node.js and Express.

item.title: 10 Year Challenge Generator
item.description: I don’t care if Mark Zuckerberg created this challenge to get face recognition data or it was just one of these internet viral things. I saw that at least 20 friends of mine did it on Facebook. So I coded a way to do it automatically! It was fun :)

item.title: Student Playbook
item.description:
This is a project to be used internally at Fullstack Academy of Code. Main purpose is to create projects and tasks for incoming students in Asana and edit all of them at once. PostgreSQL database is used to keep the tasks and projects data. Node/Express server is used to communicate with database and Asana API. React and Blueprint.js are used in the front-end. Whole project is written in TypeScript!

  • Worked with other software developers and supervised by campus director, Ben Neiswander.
  • Project aims to create a full-stack website for bulk creating and updating projects with tasks for students at Fullstack Academy.
  • My involvement was to create front-end with React, Node.js, JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

item.title: Yesternow
item.description:
• Full e-commerce experience for guest and logged in users and with admin dashboard.
  • Utilized: Node.js, Express, PostgreSQL, Sequelize, Passport, OAuth, Webpack, Babel, Mocha, Chai, Enzyme, React, Redux, Semantic UI, HTML, CSS.
  • Done in a group of 4 students in an agile work environment.
Preview

item.title: Why I hate React Native and Love at the same time.
item.description:
You can find the original post HERE.

All the big loves start with hatred, right? At least, it was the case for me with React Native. I wanted to learn it so hard. Even though it gave me really hard time when I begin to learn it, I started to love it later. Let’s find out together why I hate and love React Native at the same time!

You might be asking now: why the hell this photo? Right, we don’t have those phones at our homes anymore. (Actually, I have an older one but just for decoration.) But we have our smartphones which are like oxygen these day. You can’t live without them. In today’s world where almost everything can be done on a mobile phone, developing solutions to today’s problems in a mobile environment is a necessity. Almost every company is building mobile apps these days. So learning how to build a mobile app was always exciting for me. For a quick start, I wanted to learn React Native because I was already a master in React, so I could transfer my knowledge easily over to React Native. Yeah, right. It wasn’t that easy…

In my first big project with React Native, I wanted to make an app that will track your song skip times in Spotify and delete a song from your playlist after some number of skips. So I wanted to connect my app to Spotify via Spotify SDK. Then all the crashes and bloody red screens started to be my nightmares. I was finding a problem and fixing it, apparently to find out another problem. Main reason for all those problems was incompatibilities. There were 5 different versions that needed to be working together well to have an app working flawless: Android SDK, graddle, React Native, Spotify SDK, and a third party library for using Spotify SDK with React Native.

The latter library was to make everything smoother but apparently it was not maintained well. So I had a lot of issues and tried different versions of React Native which crashed due to incompatibility with the Android versions. At the end, I found the solution to go into node modules and change some stuff in that library which made me so proud of myself at the end. Overall, the problem was mainly incompatible versions due to the fast-growing pace of React Native.

But I couldn’t stop developing with React Native. Later, I started another project with 3 other brilliant people at Fullstack Academy and we chose to use React Native in our project. Luckily, we had less problems in that project and all of us loved it. None of us were experts on mobile development before but in one week, we were at a level where we can build an app that works in both Android and iOS phones. And not just an app, but actually a good-looking, bunch of cool features loaded, and useful app… This was such a good feeling!

I am not an expert on mobile app development area but I saw that some of the companies are changing their mobile development stack to use React Native for both Android and iOS platforms. This is actually very smart for companies as they would only hire one set of engineers to build the app in both platforms and both apps would look similar. And they would not have two teams racing each other to bring the best features fastest. That’s the case, right? I don’t know, but imagining… :) I know for sure that users race at least. Like, oh did you see Instagram added this crazy feature in their stories. — No, I didn’t. I have an Android. How many times you heard this conversation?

In conclusion, React Native is fun to learn despite all technicalities. And I see a bright future for React Native. GO RN!

item.title: About Me
item.description:
Hey! This is Mustafa. I am a software engineer with a strong passion to coding, learning, and teaching which makes me a constant learner. I like learning new languages, technologies, and libraries. I often find myself reading blog posts about other technologies, watching tutorials, and tinkering with new techs by coding with them!

Currently, I work as a Teaching Fellow at Fullstack Academy of Code in Chicago where I graduated a few months ago. I enjoy teaching coding and algorithms; also weirdly, debugging. I know, right? Sometimes I respect bugs as they take our precious hours where we are dealing with bloody deadlines. And once I found it, I am like uh-huh, there you are! Now, get out of my code! At Fullstack Academy, I daily help students to debug their codes and it is the best feeling when you see the students amazed after finding the bug.

If I am not coding, I might be snowboarding, rollerblading, or flying my drone (In fact, background image of this page was taken by my drone).

Please check my GitHub Profile for my work: https://www.github.com/mustafadane

Education

  • 2018 - Software Engineering Immersive Certificate, Fullstack Academy of Code

  • 2017 - PhD level courses, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

  • 2015 - B.S. in Molecular Biology and Genetics, Bogazici University, Istanbul, Turkey

Places I’ve worked

  • 2019 - Present- Software Engineer and Teaching Fellow, Fullstack Academy of Code, Chicago, IL

  • 2015 - 2017 - Research Assistant, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

  • 2014 - Research Assistant, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA

  • 2013 - Research Assistant, University of California, San Diego, CA

My Skills

JavaScript, TypeScript, HTML5, CSS, Python, C, Node.js, React, React Native, Redux, Express, Expo, OOP, TDD, APIs, AJAX, Agile, Pair programming, PostgreSQL, MySQL, Firebase Real-time Database, Sequelize, Mocha, Chai, Enzyme, Socket.io, Webpack, Babel.js, Git, GitHub
